section.p:
The Services table contains a nested list the services and subservices that are associated with an application.
Click the arrow beside a service name to expand or collapse the contents.
Click a service name to access a service details page.
The Status column shows whether the service is started or stopped.
In the Health column, icons indicate

row.entry:
The service name and its relationship to the preceding service.
Services at the same level are peers.
An indented service is a subservice of the preceding service. Click a service name to access its details page.
The current state of the service, represented by an icon.
The state of the service is unknown.

The name of the resource pool host on which an instance of the service is running.
If more than one instance is running, the number is noted parenthetically.
The host name is a link to the Hosts details page.
The bash command that starts an instance of the service in a container.

The controls for starting and stopping a service.
The Stop control stops all instances of the service, and discards the containers in which the instances were running.
The Start control creates new containers for the required number of instances, and use the startup command to start instances in the containers.
